In this case, using up the available fuel (oxygen), is effectively the same as air flow.

When you lift the glass allowing for the possibility of circulation, it doesn't circulate because you have hot carbon-oxides filling the glass keeping the O2 based fuel out, meaning the candle is using up all the fuel it has available.

This should be cause while neutral temperature CO2 is heavier than O2, when heated in an enclosure it will become lighter than the surrounding air, filling the glass and effectively creating a weak seal against more of the O2 from getting into the glass, as long as the flame is converting more O2 into CO2 faster than the CO2 can cool enough to exit the glass, letting in more fuel.
Candle needs to breathe too!!! :) ■ Happy physicsing.
i imaging some rich people drinking the gas from dry ice as if it was a fancy drink

One way to put out a candle from me .. For this one you need a source of high voltage, with which you can make sparks. The next step is to wide the spark gap so much, that the spark is not happening, but the generator is still working. Now you put the flame of the candle in the middle of the gap and it goes out. What is happening is the so called ionic wind, which consists of moving particles between the two voltage potentials of the spark gap. So you make a flow in the air with high voltage and you put out the candle :)

Hey, Physics Girl! I'm curious about something. Actually, about everything, but this question is about just one thing. We've all seen or done the experiment with the candle in a shallow dish of water, and then the candle is covered by a glass. Water rises into the glass because, we are told, the oxygen has been consumed. HOWEVER, as the O2 was consumed, CO2 was produced, so why does the water rise into the glass? You'd end up with the same number of molecules of CO2 as you had of O2 to begin with, and those molecules would be BIGGER. What's going on?

The density difference between N2 and air (79% N2) doesn't make that difference. The Temperature of the N2 gas is still much closer to -196 deg C. That temperature difference makes the N2 more dense than the surrounding air containing O2. Thats why the candle is put out before the liquid nitrogen hits.

My uncle was a physics teacher, and on his last ever day of school-teaching he asked his first year class if they wanted to see some really unusual ways to put out a candle.
He used the liquid nitrogen one, I think he did CO2 as well, he used a blast of sound from a loudspeaker and then for the final one (it turned out he'd been drinking at lunchtime) he unzipped his trousers and about 2 minutes later the candle was completely extinguished. That was his last day of teaching - such a shame - he was only 29.
That was so much fun. I can't wait to do it with my kids!  Thank you!

I would like to note that the dry does not actually release as much co^2 as you would think. I work in an industry where I have had access to co^2 detectors and can barely ever get a reading by putting the detector in a sealed container with the dry ice. In your example there it was actually mostly condensation from the air (the fog) that put the candle out.

The principle that makes air stick to a curved surface is called the "Coanda Effect" and is largely responsible for why wings curved on the top have lift.   More significant than the Bernoulli Effect which is still taught in some physics classes as the mechanism for lift.
